text: How would you say to ventilate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say to separate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in English what we pronounce is separate maybe like an E sound, but if you look at how it's written it's an A.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Another way to remember this is homo sapien, there's that connection there.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The homo sapien is the wise creature, supposedly.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we can remember that convenient is with coming, when things come together they are convenient.

text: We've seen the two forms of the verb end in R and the I form most of the time ends in O.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, I want, how was that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I owe, which we can use like must.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Unless the verb is irregular, and we know some irregular verbs already.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that doesn't end in O or in O.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, all two verbs, all verbs in the TO form when we say to go, to want, to segregate.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say to segregate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: All of them in the TO form end in the letter R.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They either end in AR, ER, or IR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have an example of each.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have like a thousand examples of the ones that end in AR because this is the word that we're using to build these from, for example, simulation, simulación, simular.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What do you think respirar means?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we could say to respire, really literally, or we go, oh, of course, this would be how I would say breathe in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we have many examples of AR verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have one example of an ER verb in its TO form, which is to know.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we have the example of the verb ending IR, IR, which is to come.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So all TO forms are going to end in an R, and it's either going to be AR, ER, or IR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In fact, I'm talking about two forms, and it's actually with these two that we identify what is a verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, it's good to talk about this, because at school we learned that verbs are doing words, which is really kind of unhelpful, because TO BE, for example, is there's nothing, you're not doing anything.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you say IS, he is here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: IS is a verb because it comes from TO BE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't say he BE here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the way we identify what is a verb is that you can put TO in front of it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: TO BE, TO STAY, TO GO.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And in Spanish, these are going to end in AR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, the way we get the I version is we take off this ending.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We chop off this AR, ER, or IR, and we put O.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We know how is TO try.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we take off AR, and we put on O.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But something else is happening as well.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Intentar, we have the accent on the end.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When we put the O, the accent is just before it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If I say intento, if I put the accent on the end, it means something else.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It means he tried, which is going to be useful for us later when we learn the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For now, we need to think that the accent in the present tense is going on the penultimate syllable, the second last syllable.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Part of the present tense, other than putting this O for I, is also moving the accent.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say to donate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You take off the AR, and you put O.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I don't donate, or I'm not donating.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you say I eat, or I'm eating?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for late in Spanish is tarde.

text: Now in Spanish, if you have some kind of future context, something that's showing you that you're talking about the future, you can't just use the present.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can say voy a comer mañana, or you can just say I eat tomorrow.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because you have tomorrow showing you that you're talking about the future.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's absolutely perfect Spanish, even though it sounds a bit odd in English.

speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what did that mean literally?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we can just use the present.

text: So we are taking off our ending.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We are taking off our R, R or R and we are adding O to get the I version.

speaker: Speaker 1

text: The syllable that comes before the last.

text: Now how do you say I organize or I'm organizing?

text: I will just mention for anybody trying to keep up with the Spanish pronunciation, that Z there is going to be pronounced Z.

text: To have in Spanish is tener.

speaker: Speaker 1

text: I'm going to have it late.

text: If you want to say later, you can say more late.

text: And the word for more is más.

text: I'm going to have it later.

text: I will tell you something that's going to help you remember tener.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Tener is a very interesting verb because other than to have, we can also translate it as contain.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say obtain in Spanish?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sustain, this one changes a little bit.

text: Sus, which is S-U-S, becomes S-O-S in Spanish.

text: So how would you say maintain?

speaker: Speaker 1

text: And entre in Spanish means between.

text: You might hear in Spanish, entre tú y yo.

text: Many languages express this idea of possession in different ways.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In English and in Spanish, we have a simple verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But Arabic, for example, you would say at me or with me instead of I have.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's not a straightforward concept that all languages express in the same way this concept of possession.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In Turkish, for example, if you want to say I have a car, you say my car there is.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's not such a straightforward concept that we are expressing in all languages in the same way this concept of possession.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Something that Spanish is alluding to here is kind of the symbiotic relationship in ownership.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When you own something, you also belong to it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You don't just own things, you are also owned by them.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you also get these other verbs that you can use.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Yes, it's what it should be, but it's irregular.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It has a G popping up.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But the nice thing about the irregular verbs in Spanish is that we can group them together.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There's always a little group of verbs that do things in the same way.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, what was to come?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, venir behaves like tener when it makes the I form.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if tener becomes tengo, venir might become...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But we've already noticed two verbs that have the same pattern of irregularity.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And to think of them together helps us.

text: Now, if you want to say I will come tomorrow, we don't know the word for will, but we don't need it because tomorrow is our future context.
